intro: Arundinaria radiata, commonly known as the golden bamboo, is a species of grass native to Southeast Asia. It is characterized by its tall, slender stalks and bright yellow to golden-green leaves that give it its common name. The plant is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is also used in traditional medicine. It prefers moist, well-drained soils and thrives in partial to full sunlight. Arundinaria radiata is a clump-forming perennial that can reach heights of up to 6 feet, making it a striking addition to gardens and landscapes.
